context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: What we suggest is that when the state asserts the power to dictate the details of intimacies in what they call irresponsible liaison, even in the privacy of the home, that it has a burden to justify its law through some form of tightened scrutiny.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: In your concurring opinion, Justice Powell, in Kelly versus Johnson when you suggested that a regulation on the length of hair if applied across the board to all citizens, unlike that case which was just the police, would involve an important personal liberty interest, would require a balancing of state interest against personal interest, and cited the Harlan dissent in Poe v. Ullman, I think what you recognized in that case and what I would stress here is that when a state's assertion of power over liberty occurs at the intersection of intimate personal association, which this Court has recognized in a half-century of cases, and the privacy of the home in the clearest possible sense, then there must be at least heightened scrutiny rather than the unquestioning deference that the State of Georgia would request.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I am not sure that you have answered Justice Powell's question about incest in the privacy of the home?

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, as to incest, it seems to me quite apart from problems about offspring and whatever genetic evidence there might be.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: For Fourth Amendment purposes, hotel room overnight gets full protection.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: But, when this Court decided in Payton that one needs a warrant to enter a private home even with probable cause, it is not clear to me that that decision which reflected, as your concurring opinion in Rakas did, the sense that there is something special about a home, would automatically extend to a hotel room.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: I mentioned something special about a home in Moore also against East Cleveland.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: You mentioned Poe against Ullman, but doesn't Justice Harlan in his dissenting opinion exclude sodomy when he was talking about the history of relationships?

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: Justice Powell, I have been troubled by parts of the Harlan dissent in Moore which rather casually mentioned homosexuality, and for that matter abortion, in much the same breath.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: The actual language that I think is operative at page 552 of the Harlan dissent is that he would not suggest... He says that

context.text: But, this Court has never before held that when a personal right protected by the Constitution, just because those persons might be able to obtain political redress, the right no longer deserves judicial protection.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: What has happened in 25 years?

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: I do not think that if this case had been squarely presented before Justice Harlan that he would have decided to draw the line based on which body parts come into contact.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: There is no suggestion, for instance, that the part of this law which involves aggravated sodomy is under attack.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: The argument, however, is that this law in its sweeping definition of intimacies in the home is unconstitutional and--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I thought your response to Justice Powell was that a hotel room, back seat of a car, no.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: --That is correct.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: We don't rely on peculiarities of the facts here, but we do say that it is only in the context of the home that the very powerful confluence of rights represented by the home and intimacy are involved.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: When the government would tell people in this much detail how to conduct their intimate lives and doesn't apparently have a good enough reason to keep Mr. Hardwick in something other than a limbo in which he could be prosecuted any time until August under this extraordinarily sweeping law, when it does that, it seems to us that it is fully respectful of history and tradition for the Eleventh Circuit to have said you owe Mr. Hardwick a better reason and you owe the people of the United States a better reason than simply unquestioned deference.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: And, I think Justice Harlan, if the issue had been properly posed in Poe v. Ullman which, of course, didn't involve this, would have recognized that requirement of meaningful justification.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
context.text: Even if you only call it rationality review, it is rationality review with meaningful content of the kind this Court recognized in the Cleburne case.

context.text: Mr. Tribe, I am curious to know, you have referred to Justice White's opinion in Moore v. Cleveland.

context.speaker: Laurence H. Tribe
